expanded_description: Weight is the gravitational force exerted on an object by a massive body like Earth. Understanding weight, how it differs from mass, and how it relates to gravitational acceleration is essential for analyzing motion and forces in physics.

core_concept.principle: Weight is the force of gravity acting on an object, calculated as $W = mg$ where $m$ is mass (kg) and $g$ is gravitational field strength or acceleration due to gravity (9.8 m/s² on Earth's surface). Weight is a force measured in newtons (N), while mass is the amount of matter measured in kilograms (kg). Weight varies with location (different $g$ values), but mass remains constant everywhere.
core_concept.explanation: Weight and mass are fundamentally different but related concepts. Mass is an intrinsic property of matter—the quantity of material in an object and its resistance to acceleration (inertia). Mass is the same whether you're on Earth, the Moon, or in deep space. Weight is the gravitational force acting on that mass. On Earth, weight = $mg$ where $g = 9.8$ m/s². On the Moon, $g = 1.6$ m/s², so the same mass weighs much less. In space far from any massive body, $g \approx 0$, so weight ≈ 0 (weightlessness), but mass unchanged. Key points: (1) Weight is a force (vector), measured in newtons. Mass is a scalar, measured in kilograms. (2) Weight depends on location ($g$ varies). Mass is constant everywhere. (3) Weight always points toward the center of the massive body (downward on Earth). (4) At Earth's surface, $g = 9.8$ m/s² ≈ 10 m/s² (often approximated for easier calculations). (5) The value of $g$ is both the gravitational field strength (N/kg) and the free-fall acceleration (m/s²)—numerically the same. (6) Normal force often equals weight for objects at rest on horizontal surfaces, but they are different forces (normal from surface, weight from Earth). Weight causes numerous effects: objects fall when dropped, require support forces to remain stationary, create compression in structures, determine how hard objects are to lift. Understanding weight is crucial for analyzing forces in statics (objects at rest) and dynamics (falling objects, objects on scales, apparent weight in accelerating reference frames).

sections.introduction: Weight is the force of gravity acting on an object with mass. It's one of the most common forces we encounter.

key_concept.definition: Weight $W$ is the gravitational force exerted on an object by a massive body (like Earth, Moon, or planet). Near Earth's surface: $W = mg$ where $m$ is object's mass (kg) and $g = 9.8$ m/s² is Earth's gravitational field strength (approximately 10 m/s² for simpler calculations).
key_concept.context: Every object with mass experiences gravitational attraction to nearby massive bodies. On Earth, this is 'weight'—the familiar force pulling everything downward. Weight is always present on objects near Earth's surface, whether stationary or moving, whether on the ground or in the air.

principles.statement: Weight equals mass times gravitational field strength: $W = mg$. On Earth's surface, $g = 9.8$ m/s² (or approximately 10 m/s²).
principles.application: To find weight: multiply mass by $g$. To find mass: divide weight by $g$.
principles.example: Mass 5 kg: $W = 5 \times 9.8 = 49$ N on Earth. Mass 70 kg: $W = 70 \times 9.8 = 686$ N on Earth.

principles.statement: Weight is a force, measured in newtons (N). It's a vector pointing toward Earth's center (downward at Earth's surface).
principles.application: Show weight as downward arrow on free-body diagrams. Include in net force calculations.
principles.example: 10 kg object: weight = 98 N downward. On free-body diagram: arrow labeled '$W = 98$ N' or '$F_g = 98$ N' pointing down.

principles.statement: Near Earth's surface, weight points vertically downward (toward Earth's center). This is true whether object is at rest, moving, on surface, or in air.
principles.application: Always draw weight arrow pointing down (Earth's direction) on FBDs.
principles.example: Ball thrown upward: weight still points down (opposes upward motion, causes deceleration). Ball falling: weight points down (accelerates ball downward). Ball at rest on table: weight points down (balanced by normal force).

principles.statement: $g$ has two equivalent interpretations: (1) Gravitational field strength (force per unit mass): N/kg. (2) Gravitational acceleration (free-fall acceleration): m/s². Numerically identical on Earth's surface: $g = 9.8$ N/kg = 9.8 m/s².
principles.application: Use $g = 9.8$ m/s² for calculations (or $g = 10$ m/s² for approximations).
principles.example: Field strength view: 1 kg experiences 9.8 N force. 2 kg experiences 19.6 N. Force proportional to mass. Acceleration view: All objects accelerate at 9.8 m/s² in free fall regardless of mass.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Weight from Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the weight of: (a) 8 kg backpack, (b) 1500 kg car, (c) 0.2 kg apple.

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg$ with $g = 9.8$ m/s²

worked_examples.concept_applied: Weight = mass × $g$. Multiply mass (kg) by 9.8 m/s² to get weight (N).

worked_examples.title: Finding Mass from Weight
worked_examples.problem: An object weighs 245 N on Earth. What is its mass?

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg$ → $m = \frac{W}{g}$
$m = \frac{245 \text{ N}}{9.8 \text{ m/s}^2}$
N/(m/s²) = (kg⋅m/s²)/(m/s²) = kg ✓

worked_examples.concept_applied: From weight, find mass: $m = W/g$. Divide weight (N) by 9.8 m/s² to get mass (kg).

worked_examples.title: Weight in Free-Body Diagram
worked_examples.problem: A 12 kg box sits on a table. Include weight in the free-body diagram and calculate its magnitude.

step_by_step.explanation: Box drawn as simple rectangle. Arrow pointing downward from center, labeled '$W = 117.6$ N' or '$F_g = 117.6$ N' or 'Weight 117.6 N.' Also include normal force upward (equal to weight if box at rest on horizontal surface).

worked_examples.final_answer: Weight = 117.6 N downward. FBD shows downward arrow labeled 117.6 N.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Weight always included on FBD for objects with mass. Points downward, magnitude = $mg$.

image.caption: Weight calculation: $W = mg$ where $m$ is mass (kg) and $g = 9.8$ m/s²

sections.introduction: Mass and weight are related but fundamentally different. Confusing them is a common error that leads to conceptual and calculation mistakes.

key_concept.definition: Mass is the quantity of matter in an object, measured in kilograms (kg). It's an intrinsic scalar property, constant everywhere. Weight is the gravitational force on that mass, measured in newtons (N). It's a vector force that varies with gravitational field strength.
key_concept.context: In everyday language, people often say 'I weigh 70 kg' when they mean 'my mass is 70 kg.' Scientifically, 70 kg is mass, not weight. The weight would be 686 N (using $W = mg = 70 \times 9.8$).

principles.statement: Your mass is the same on Earth, Moon, Mars, or in space. Your weight changes because gravitational field strength $g$ differs in each location.
principles.application: Mass: intrinsic property, doesn't change with location. Weight: depends on local $g$.
principles.example: 70 kg astronaut: Mass 70 kg everywhere. Weight on Earth: $W = 70 \times 9.8 = 686$ N. Weight on Moon ($g = 1.6$ m/s²): $W = 70 \times 1.6 = 112$ N. Weight in space ($g \approx 0$): $W \approx 0$ N (weightless but still 70 kg mass!).

principles.statement: Mass: kilograms (kg), scalar. Weight: newtons (N), vector (force).
principles.application: kg → mass. N → weight (force).
principles.example: Correct: 'Mass is 50 kg, weight is 490 N.' Incorrect: 'I weigh 50 kg' (should be 'my mass is 50 kg' or 'I weigh 490 N').

principles.principle: Mass Measures Inertia, Weight Measures Gravitational Pull
principles.statement: Mass quantifies resistance to acceleration (inertia). Weight quantifies gravitational force strength.
principles.application: Mass in Second Law ($F = ma$). Weight as force in force equations.
principles.example: Pushing 5 kg object vs 50 kg object: 50 kg harder to accelerate (more inertia, larger mass). On Moon, both objects weigh less than on Earth, but their inertia (mass) unchanged—still just as hard to push horizontally.

principles.statement: Mass measured with balance scale (compares to standard masses, works anywhere). Weight measured with spring scale (measures force, reading changes with $g$).
principles.application: Balance scale: mass. Spring scale: weight (force).
principles.example: Balance scale on Moon shows same 70 kg as on Earth (compares masses). Spring scale on Moon shows lower reading (less gravitational force).

examples.explanation: Mass: amount of matter, resistance to acceleration. Weight: gravitational force on mass.
Mass: scalar (magnitude only). Weight: vector (magnitude and direction).
Mass: constant everywhere in universe. Weight: varies with location ($g$ changes).
Mass: intrinsic property, independent of environment. Weight: depends on gravitational field ($W = mg$).
Mass: balance scale. Weight: spring scale or force sensor.
Mass: never zero (unless truly no matter). Weight: zero in deep space or free fall (weightlessness).

worked_examples.title: Mass and Weight on Different Celestial Bodies
worked_examples.problem: An astronaut has mass 80 kg. Find weight on: (a) Earth ($g = 9.8$ m/s²), (b) Moon ($g = 1.6$ m/s²), (c) Mars ($g = 3.7$ m/s²), (d) Deep space ($g \approx 0$). (e) What is astronaut's mass in each location?

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg = 80 \times 1.6 = 128$ N (about 1/6 of Earth weight)
$W = mg = 80 \times 3.7 = 296$ N (about 3/8 of Earth weight)
$W = mg = 80 \times 0 = 0$ N (weightless)
Mass = 80 kg on Earth, Moon, Mars, and space. Mass is constant—doesn't change with location.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 784 N, (b) 128 N, (c) 296 N, (d) 0 N. (e) Mass is 80 kg everywhere.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Weight = $mg$ varies with $g$ (location-dependent). Mass constant everywhere. Same mass, different weights on different bodies.

worked_examples.title: Correcting Common Language
worked_examples.problem: Rewrite the following correctly: 'I weigh 65 kg,' 'The package weighs 5000 grams,' 'Astronauts are weightless in space so they have no mass.'

step_by_step.explanation: 'I weigh 65 kg' → WRONG (kg is mass unit, not weight). Correct: 'My mass is 65 kg' or 'I weigh 637 N' (using $W = 65 \times 9.8$).
'Package weighs 5000 grams' → WRONG (grams is mass unit). Correct: 'Package's mass is 5000 grams (5 kg)' or 'Package weighs 49 N.'

'Astronauts weightless so no mass' → WRONG. Weightless means weight ≈ 0 (no gravitational force or in free fall). Mass unchanged. Correct: 'Astronauts are weightless in space (weight ≈ 0) but their mass remains the same.'

worked_examples.final_answer: Corrections: (1) 'My mass is 65 kg' or 'I weigh 637 N.' (2) 'Mass is 5 kg' or 'Weighs 49 N.' (3) 'Astronauts weightless but mass unchanged.'
worked_examples.concept_applied: Common language often confuses mass and weight. kg = mass. N = weight. Weightless ≠ massless.

image.caption: Mass vs Weight: mass constant (80 kg everywhere), weight varies (784 N on Earth, 128 N on Moon)

sections.section_title: Gravitational Field Strength and Free Fall
sections.introduction: The value $g = 9.8$ m/s² has dual meaning: gravitational field strength (force per mass) and free-fall acceleration. Understanding this connects weight to motion.

key_concept.definition: Gravitational field strength $g$ at a location is the gravitational force per unit mass: $g = F_g/m$ (units: N/kg). For free-falling objects, $g$ also equals the acceleration: $a = g$ (units: m/s²). Numerically, N/kg = m/s², so $g = 9.8$ N/kg = 9.8 m/s² on Earth's surface.
key_concept.context: This dual interpretation explains why all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass. Heavy objects have more weight ($F_g = mg$ larger), but also more inertia (mass larger). These effects exactly cancel in free fall: $a = F_g/m = mg/m = g$ (mass cancels).

principles.statement: $g$ as field strength: force per unit mass (N/kg). Each kilogram experiences 9.8 N force. $g$ as acceleration: free-fall acceleration (m/s²). All objects accelerate at 9.8 m/s² downward when falling.
principles.application: Use $g$ in $W = mg$ for weight (field strength view). Use $g$ in $a = g$ for free-fall motion (acceleration view).
principles.example: Field view: 10 kg object experiences $F_g = 10 \times 9.8 = 98$ N. Acceleration view: 10 kg object falls with $a = 9.8$ m/s². Both use same $g$ value.

principles.principle: All Objects Fall at Same Rate
principles.statement: In free fall (ignoring air resistance), all objects accelerate at $g = 9.8$ m/s² downward regardless of mass. Feather and hammer fall identically in vacuum.
principles.application: Free-fall acceleration independent of mass. Galileo's and Newton's insight.
principles.example: Drop 1 kg ball and 10 kg ball simultaneously from same height. Both hit ground at same time (ignoring air resistance). Both accelerate at 9.8 m/s² despite different weights (9.8 N vs 98 N).

principles.principle: Why Mass Cancels in Free Fall
principles.statement: Free fall: only force is weight $F_g = mg$ (downward). Apply Second Law: $F_g = ma$. Substitute: $mg = ma$. Cancel $m$: $a = g$. Mass appears on both sides, cancels.
principles.application: Mathematical proof that free-fall acceleration independent of mass.
principles.example: Heavy object: $F_g = 100$ N, $m = 10$ kg. $a = F/m = 100/10 = 10$ m/s². Light object: $F_g = 10$ N, $m = 1$ kg. $a = 10/1 = 10$ m/s². Same acceleration despite different masses and weights.

principles.statement: $g$ varies with location: altitude (decreases slightly with height), latitude (slightly less at equator due to Earth's rotation and shape), celestial body (Moon, Mars, Jupiter all have different $g$ values).
principles.application: For most problems, use $g = 9.8$ m/s² or 10 m/s² at Earth's surface. Specify different values when relevant.
principles.example: At sea level: $g = 9.81$ m/s². At altitude 400 km (ISS orbit): $g \approx 8.7$ m/s² (still substantial, not zero—astronauts feel weightless due to free fall, not lack of gravity).

worked_examples.title: Gravitational Field Strength Calculation
worked_examples.problem: On a certain planet, a 4 kg object weighs 24 N. (a) What is the gravitational field strength on this planet? (b) What would be the free-fall acceleration on this planet?

step_by_step.explanation: $g = \frac{W}{m} = \frac{24 \text{ N}}{4 \text{ kg}}$
Numerically same as field strength: $g = 6$ m/s²

On this planet, each kilogram experiences 6 N gravitational force (field strength). Dropped objects accelerate at 6 m/s² (free-fall acceleration). Both expressed as $g = 6$ (N/kg or m/s²—numerically identical).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Gravitational field strength $g = W/m$ (N/kg) equals free-fall acceleration (m/s²) numerically.

worked_examples.title: Free Fall Independence of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Two balls (masses 2 kg and 8 kg) are dropped from rest at the same height on Earth. (a) Compare their weights. (b) Compare their free-fall accelerations. (c) Which hits the ground first?

step_by_step.explanation: Ball 1: $W_1 = 2 \times 9.8 = 19.6$ N. Ball 2: $W_2 = 8 \times 9.8 = 78.4$ N. Ball 2 weighs 4 times more (proportional to mass).
Both free-falling with only gravity acting. Ball 1: $a_1 = F/m = 19.6/2 = 9.8$ m/s². Ball 2: $a_2 = 78.4/8 = 9.8$ m/s². Same acceleration despite different weights and masses.

Both have same acceleration (9.8 m/s²), dropped from same height, starting from rest. Kinematics: $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}at^2$ → time depends on $a$ and $\Delta x$ only. Same $a$ and same $\Delta x$ → same time. Hit simultaneously (ignoring air resistance).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Ball 2 weighs 4× more. (b) Both accelerate at 9.8 m/s². (c) Hit simultaneously.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Free-fall acceleration independent of mass. Heavier weight exactly compensated by greater inertia. All objects fall at same rate.

image.alt: Diagram showing heavy and light objects falling at same rate with same acceleration
image.caption: Free fall: all objects accelerate at $g$ regardless of mass. Heavy and light fall together (ignoring air resistance).

sections.introduction: Weight and normal force are often related but are distinct forces. Understanding their relationship and differences prevents confusion.

key_concept.definition: Weight is the gravitational force from Earth (or other massive body), always pointing downward. Normal force is the contact force from a surface, always perpendicular to that surface. For object at rest on horizontal surface, $F_N = W$ (magnitudes equal), but they are different forces from different sources acting in opposite directions.
key_concept.context: On free-body diagram of object on horizontal surface at rest: weight points down (from Earth), normal points up (from surface). They balance (net vertical force = 0), but they're not action-reaction pairs (both act on same object, different types).

principles.principle: Weight and Normal Are Different Forces
principles.statement: Weight: from Earth (gravity), always downward, magnitude $W = mg$. Normal: from surface (contact), perpendicular to surface, magnitude adjusts to situation.
principles.application: Don't confuse or conflate them. Both appear on same object's FBD but from different sources.
principles.example: Book on table: weight from Earth (10 N down), normal from table (10 N up). Two separate forces, different origins, happen to have equal magnitudes for this stationary case.

principles.principle: Normal Force Adjusts to Prevent Penetration
principles.statement: Normal force magnitude adjusts automatically to prevent object from sinking into surface. Can be less than, equal to, or greater than weight depending on other forces and acceleration.
principles.application: $F_N = W$ only for object at rest on horizontal surface with no vertical forces besides weight and normal.
principles.example: At rest on horizontal surface: $F_N = W$ (balanced). On incline: $F_N < W$ (normal only balances perpendicular component of weight). In accelerating elevator upward: $F_N > W$ (must provide net upward force).

principles.principle: Weight Always Constant Near Earth, Normal Varies
principles.statement: For given object near Earth's surface, weight = $mg$ stays constant (same $m$, same $g$). Normal force changes based on surface orientation, other forces, acceleration.
principles.application: Weight doesn't change with circumstances. Normal force does.
principles.example: 10 kg object: weight always 98 N downward near Earth's surface. Normal: 98 N when at rest on floor, less on incline, zero when in air, more when in accelerating elevator upward. Weight unchanged, normal varies.

principles.statement: Weight and normal force on object at rest on horizontal surface are NOT action-reaction pair (Third Law). Both act on same object. Different types. They're balanced forces (equilibrium), not action-reaction.
principles.application: Balanced forces ≠ action-reaction pair. Check: same object → not action-reaction.
principles.example: Action-reaction pairs for book on table: (1) Earth pulls book (weight) ↔ book pulls Earth. (2) Book pushes table ↔ table pushes book (normal). Weight and normal both on book → not action-reaction pair.

worked_examples.title: Weight and Normal for Object at Rest
worked_examples.problem: A 15 kg box sits at rest on a horizontal floor. (a) Find weight. (b) Find normal force. (c) Explain relationship.

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg = 15 \times 9.8 = 147$ N downward
Box at rest → no vertical acceleration → net vertical force = 0. Vertical forces: weight 147 N down, normal $F_N$ up. $F_N - W = 0$ → $F_N = W = 147$ N upward

Weight and normal have equal magnitudes (147 N) and opposite directions (down vs up) for this case because box is at rest on horizontal surface. They balance each other (equilibrium). But they're different forces: weight from Earth (gravity), normal from floor (contact). Both act on box (same object), so NOT action-reaction pair.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $W = 147$ N down, (b) $F_N = 147$ N up, (c) Equal magnitudes, opposite directions, balance for equilibrium—but different forces (not action-reaction pair).
worked_examples.concept_applied: For object at rest on horizontal surface: $F_N = W$ (balanced forces). Weight and normal are different forces that happen to be equal in this situation.

worked_examples.title: Normal Force Less Than Weight
worked_examples.problem: A 6 kg object rests on a ramp inclined at 30° from horizontal. The normal force is perpendicular to the ramp surface. (a) Find weight. (b) Is normal force equal to weight? (c) Find normal force magnitude.

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg = 6 \times 9.8 = 58.8$ N vertically downward
No. Weight points vertically down. Normal perpendicular to ramp (at angle). They can't balance—different directions. Normal force does NOT equal weight on incline.

Weight component perpendicular to ramp: $W_{\perp} = W \cos 30° = 58.8 \times 0.866 = 50.9$ N. No acceleration perpendicular to surface → normal balances perpendicular component: $F_N = W_{\perp} = 50.9$ N. Less than weight.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $W = 58.8$ N down, (b) No, normal ≠ weight on incline, (c) $F_N = 50.9$ N perpendicular to surface (less than weight)
worked_examples.concept_applied: On incline: normal force perpendicular to surface, less than weight. Normal balances only perpendicular component of weight.

image.alt: FBD showing weight and normal force on object, with labels distinguishing them
image.caption: Weight (from Earth, downward) and Normal (from surface, upward) are different forces. Equal magnitudes when at rest on horizontal surface.

sections.introduction: What we perceive as 'weight' (e.g., feeling of heaviness) is actually the normal force, not gravitational force. This leads to phenomena like feeling heavier in accelerating elevator or weightless in free fall.

key_concept.definition: Apparent weight is what we perceive as our weight—actually the normal force (or support force) we feel from surfaces. In elevator accelerating upward: apparent weight > actual weight (feel heavier). In elevator accelerating downward or free fall: apparent weight < actual weight or zero (feel lighter or weightless). Actual weight (gravitational force $mg$) remains constant; apparent weight (normal force) changes.
key_concept.context: Bathroom scale measures normal force, not weight directly. When you feel heavy or light, you're sensing changes in normal force, not changes in gravitational force (which stays constant near Earth).

principles.statement: What you 'feel' as weight is the normal force pushing on you. Scale reading = normal force magnitude, not gravitational force directly.
principles.application: Feeling heavy → large normal force. Feeling weightless → zero normal force.
principles.example: Standing on scale in elevator: scale reads normal force. Elevator at rest: scale reads your actual weight (normal = weight). Elevator accelerating up: scale reads more than weight (normal > weight). Elevator accelerating down: scale reads less (normal < weight).

principles.statement: When accelerating upward, normal force must be greater than weight to provide net upward force: $F_N - W = ma$ → $F_N = W + ma > W$.
principles.application: Upward acceleration: apparent weight increases.
principles.example: Elevator accelerating upward at 2 m/s². Person mass 70 kg, weight 686 N. Net force needed: $F_{net} = ma = 70 \times 2 = 140$ N upward. Normal force: $F_N = W + ma = 686 + 140 = 826$ N. Feel heavier (normal force increased by 140 N).

principles.statement: When accelerating downward, normal force less than weight to provide net downward force: $W - F_N = ma$ → $F_N = W - ma < W$.
principles.application: Downward acceleration: apparent weight decreases.
principles.example: Elevator accelerating downward at 2 m/s². Same person: $F_N = W - ma = 686 - 140 = 546$ N. Feel lighter (normal force decreased by 140 N).

principles.statement: In free fall, only force is gravity (no normal force from surface). $F_N = 0$. Apparent weight = 0. Feel weightless even though gravitational force (actual weight) still acts.
principles.application: Free fall → normal force zero → apparent weight zero → weightlessness sensation.
principles.example: Astronauts in orbit: continuously free-falling toward Earth (orbit is perpetual free fall). No normal force from surfaces. Feel weightless. Actual weight (gravity) still present (~90% of surface value at ISS altitude)—it's what keeps them in orbit!

worked_examples.title: Apparent Weight in Accelerating Elevator
worked_examples.problem: A 60 kg person stands on a scale in an elevator. Find scale reading (apparent weight) when: (a) elevator at rest, (b) accelerating upward at 3 m/s², (c) accelerating downward at 2 m/s², (d) in free fall.

step_by_step.explanation: $W = mg = 60 \times 9.8 = 588$ N (constant in all cases)
No acceleration → $F_N = W = 588$ N. Scale reads 588 N (or 60 kg if calibrated as mass).
Upward acceleration $a = 3$ m/s². Need net upward force: $F_N - W = ma$. $F_N = W + ma = 588 + 60 \times 3 = 588 + 180 = 768$ N. Scale reads 768 N (feels 30% heavier).

Downward acceleration $a = 2$ m/s² (take down as positive for this calculation). Need net downward force: $W - F_N = ma$. $F_N = W - ma = 588 - 60 \times 2 = 588 - 120 = 468$ N. Scale reads 468 N (feels 20% lighter).
Accelerating downward at $a = g = 9.8$ m/s². $F_N = W - ma = 588 - 60 \times 9.8 = 588 - 588 = 0$ N. Scale reads 0 (weightless feeling, though gravity still acts).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Apparent weight = normal force. Changes with acceleration: $F_N = W + ma$ (upward $a$), $F_N = W - ma$ (downward $a$), $F_N = 0$ (free fall).

worked_examples.title: Explaining Weightlessness in Orbit
worked_examples.problem: Astronauts in International Space Station (orbiting at 400 km altitude where $g \approx 8.7$ m/s²) feel weightless. (a) Do they have weight (gravitational force)? (b) Why do they feel weightless?

step_by_step.explanation: Yes! At 400 km altitude, $g \approx 8.7$ m/s² (about 90% of surface value). Astronaut mass 70 kg: $W = 70 \times 8.7 = 609$ N. Substantial gravitational force—only 12% less than on surface. Weight definitely present.

ISS is in continuous free fall toward Earth. Orbital motion is perpetual free fall (falling 'around' Earth). Station and astronauts both accelerating downward at same rate (toward Earth's center). No normal force from floor (astronaut and floor both falling together). Apparent weight = normal force = 0. Feel weightless.
People think 'no gravity in space.' Wrong! Gravity is what keeps ISS in orbit. Weightlessness is due to free fall (no support force), not absence of gravity.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Yes, weight ≈ 609 N (gravity still strong). (b) Weightless because free-falling (no normal force), not because gravity absent.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Weightlessness = zero apparent weight (no normal force) due to free fall. Actual weight (gravity) still present—it's what maintains orbit.

image.alt: Diagram showing person in elevator with different normal forces for different accelerations
image.caption: Apparent weight: normal force varies with acceleration. At rest: FN = W. Accelerating up: FN > W (feel heavy). Free fall: FN = 0 (weightless).

summary: Weight is the gravitational force acting on an object: $W = mg$ where $m$ is mass (kg) and $g$ is gravitational field strength (N/kg or m/s²). On Earth's surface, $g = 9.8$ m/s² (often approximated as 10 m/s²). Weight is a force measured in newtons (N), always pointing toward Earth's center (downward at surface). Mass vs weight distinctions: Mass is amount of matter (kg), constant everywhere, scalar, measures inertia. Weight is gravitational force (N), varies with location ($g$ changes), vector pointing toward massive body, measures gravitational pull. Same mass has different weights on Earth (strong $g$), Moon (weak $g$), space (nearly zero $g$). Gravitational field strength $g$ has dual interpretation: (1) Force per unit mass (N/kg)—each kilogram experiences 9.8 N force on Earth. (2) Free-fall acceleration (m/s²)—all objects accelerate at 9.8 m/s² when falling. Numerically identical: 9.8 N/kg = 9.8 m/s². All objects fall at same rate regardless of mass because in free fall: $F = mg$ and $F = ma$ give $mg = ma$, so $a = g$ (mass cancels). Heavier objects have more weight but also more inertia—effects exactly cancel. Weight and normal force relationship: Weight is gravitational force from Earth (always downward, magnitude $mg$). Normal force is contact force from surface (perpendicular to surface, magnitude adjusts). For object at rest on horizontal surface: $F_N = W$ (equal magnitudes), but they're different forces from different sources, both acting on same object—NOT action-reaction pair. On inclines or with acceleration: $F_N \neq W$. Apparent weight is what we feel—actually normal force, not gravitational force. In accelerating elevator upward: $F_N = W + ma$ (feel heavier). Accelerating downward: $F_N = W - ma$ (feel lighter). Free fall: $F_N = 0$ (weightless), even though gravity still acts. Astronauts in orbit feel weightless not because gravity absent (gravity keeps them in orbit), but because they're in continuous free fall—no normal force. Understanding weight essential for analyzing forces in statics (objects at rest), dynamics (falling objects, scales, elevators), and distinguishing actual weight (gravitational force, constant) from apparent weight (normal force, varies with acceleration).
